content.title: Compartment Syndrome in Acute Limb Ischemia
content.description: Life- and limb-threatening complication of ischemia-reperfusion injury where increased tissue pressure within a closed fascial space compromises circulation.

pathophysiology.cause: Reperfusion of ischemic muscle leads to edema
pathophysiology.consequence: Continued ischemia despite patent arterial flow

clinical_features.key_point: Pulses may be present - don't wait for pulse loss

leg_compartments.anterior: Most commonly affected; tibialis anterior, extensors, deep peroneal nerve
leg_compartments.deep_posterior: Tibialis posterior, flexors, tibial nerve and vessels

diagnosis.clinical: High index of suspicion is key
diagnosis.pressure_measurement: Stryker or arterial line, >30mmHg or delta pressure <30 from diastolic

treatment.closure: Delayed primary closure, skin grafting, or vacuum-assisted closure
